sentence.Network_en: The feast was served by his mother and sisters.
sentence.Network_cn: 这顿美餐是他母亲和他的姐妹们准备的。

sentence.Network_en: Lucilla often asks her sisters to retell the story.
sentence.Network_cn: 露西拉经常要姐姐们把这个故事反复讲给她听。

sentence.Network_en: His sisters are grown up and his parents are middle-aged.
sentence.Network_cn: 他的姐妹们都已成人，而他的父母亲也人到中年。

entry.def: Your sister is a girl or woman who has the same parents as you.

example.ex: ...Vanessa Bell, the sister of Virginia Woolf...
example.tran: 弗吉尼娅·伍尔夫的姐姐瓦妮莎·贝尔

entry.def: Sister is a title given to a woman who belongs to a religious community.

example.tran: 弗朗西丝卡修女走进了小教堂。

example.ex: ...the Hospice of the Sisters of Charity at Lourdes.
example.tran: 卢尔德仁爱修女会的安养院

entry.def: A sister is a senior female nurse who supervises part of a hospital.

example.ex: Ask to speak to the sister on the ward...
example.tran: 请求和病房里的护士长说话。

example.ex: Sister Middleton followed the coffee trolley.
example.tran: 护士长米德尔顿跟在送咖啡的推车后面。

entry.tran: (同一种族、宗教、国家或职业的)姐妹;同道中的女性;志同道合的女士
entry.def: You can describe a woman as your sister if you feel a connection with her, for example because she belongs to the same race, religion, country, or profession.

example.ex: Modern woman has been freed from many of the duties that befell her sisters in times past.
example.tran: 现代女性已经从许多压在旧时女性身上的责任中解放出来了。
我们犹太教的兄弟姐妹们

entry.tran: 同类型的;相关联的;如同姐妹的
entry.def: You can use sister to describe something that is of the same type or is connected in some way to another thing you have mentioned. For example, if a company has a sister company, they are connected.

example.ex: ...the International Monetary Fund and its sister organisation, the World Bank.
example.tran: 国际货币基金组织及其姊妹机构——世界银行
“旅行者 2 号”太空探测器及其姊妹探测器——“旅行者 1 号”

Sentence.sentence: Caregivers must also learn to state their needs and opinions clearly and ask for help from others especially brothers and sisters.
Brothers and sisters are often willing to help, but they may not know what to do

In a study of older people with sisters and brothers, psychologist Debra Gold of the Duke Center for the study of aging and human development found that about 20% said they were hostile or indifferent to ward their sisters and brothers.

In a study of older people with sisters and brothers, psychologist Debra Gold of the Duke Center for the study of aging and human development found that about 20% said they were hostile or indifferent to ward their sisters and brothers.
Only four out of the 54 people interviewed had completely broken with their sisters and brothers and only one of the four felt comfortable with the break.
